text.p: These are the leading stories in the Lebanese press on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Residents of Beirut's southern suburbs threaten a rubbish revolt.
- Syrian fans attack photographers at the Pan-Arab Games in Beirut.
- Opposition MP Nassib Lahoud raps government handling of economic crisis.
- Israeli shelling and rocket attacks on south Lebanon.
- Former Hizbollah leader Sheikh Sobhi Tufaili complains of corruption in Lebanon.
Tufaili has launched a "hunger revolt" in the form of a civil disobedience campaign to pressure the government into easing poverty.
- Central bank intervention supports the Lebanese pound.
- Egypt takes first place in Pan-Arab Games which ended on Sunday.
- Prime Minister Rafik al-Hariri is abroad and the state takes a short vacation.
- Economic contacts between Lebanon and Iraq continue.

Efforts by Lebanon and Iraq to repair ties which were severed in 1994 were hampered this month after Lebanon, under pressure from Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, barred Iraqi athletes from competing in the Pan-Arab Games.
